timeline.message: FCCEUD-8 Implemented reviewer comments by adahms, daly

timeline.bodyText: I'd either use Git, the "proper" name of the tool, or mark it up in monospace to indicate a literal command (git).
timeline.author: robin-owen
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@
+[id='about-pantheon_{context}']
+= About Pantheon
+
+Pantheon is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat. You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source. After adding your modules to Pantheon, add metadata, preview modules using the look and feel of the Customer Portal, associate the module with a product, publish and unpublish the module.
+
+Pantheon provides:
+
+    A GUI for managing modules and assemblies, including the ability for authors to search for specific content and other workflow features that are more user-friendly than those currently available
+    Metadata editing to optimize content for search engines
+    A module library to enable content reuse
+    A visual preview of a module so you can see how it will appear on the customer portal
+
+Pantheon does not:
+
+    Determine the appearance of content
+    Replace git as a source control system

timeline.bodyText: This looks like a procedure. Was that intended?
timeline.author: robin-owen
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@

+= About Pantheon
+
+Pantheon is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat. You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source. After adding your modules to Pantheon, add metadata, preview modules using the look and feel of the Customer Portal, associate the module with a product, publish and unpublish the module.
+
+Pantheon provides:

+    A GUI for managing modules and assemblies, including the ability for authors to search for specific content and other workflow features that are more user-friendly than those currently available

replies.bodyText: No, but it's a series of events that takes place in a given order. Do you have a suggestion of how to better present it?
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText: Not in particular, no. I'm also not strictly against having this in the concept module, it just stood out to me as being a procedure. :)
replies.author: robin-owen

replies.bodyText:
Gotcha, @robin-owen.
@benradey I see that you can either follow the current process of submitting new content to gitlab/github, or you can upload modules/assemblies directly to Pantheon by clicking New Module in the left nav pane.
This is different than the current process of syncing Pantheon with the latest merged commit in the linked Gitlab repo. That raises two questions:

Since I have to submit my content to Gitlab/Github regardless, when would I ever upload content directly to Pantheon instead of importing it from Gitlab/Github?
Do I understand correctly the difference in process between Pantheon 1 and Pantheon 2? I.e. In Pantheon 2, I upload/import new content manually, which requires me to manually select one or more files (modules or assemblies) while in Pantheon 1 I simply sync the title to the current state of my repo?
replies.author: stoobie
benradey

replies.bodyText: @benradey This is news to all of us. So the CLI uploader script is also going away? This is a pretty big deal. I have two requests: That you update the Pantheon v2 CCS Instructions to call this out with a note or warning, and that you shoot out a mail to stakeholders to let us know.
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText: Hi Steve, the CLI uploader is not going away. In fact it will be THE way to upload content into Pantheon.
replies.author: carlosmunoz

replies.bodyText:
@stoobie The CLI script isn't going away, but the functionality that exists today (users can create publishable documents using the uploader) does not match the long term goal.
It is a design goal that all publishable documents must come in through some sort of source control (one option today: git). For MS2, we only support getting docs into the system through git. The CLI also currently works for that, but that is unsupported and that functionality will be disabled at some point.
Long term, we will introduce sandboxes, which are transient workspaces that house documents that cannot be published, and the method to populate those will primarily be the CLI tool, among other possible methods. So the CLI tool won't go away, but it will be repurposed.
I hope that clarifies the desired/intended functionality of the system. Let me know if you still have questions.
replies.author: benradey

replies.bodyText: @carlosmunoz, @benradey Now I'm more confused. The two of you appear to be contradicting each other.
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText:
Not a contradiction, we were just speaking of different time frames 😃
Ben gave a more detailed explanation, but the important message is that the CLI (uploader) is not going away.
replies.author: carlosmunoz

replies.bodyText:
OK, so at the risk of beating a dead horse, which is part of my job, let me see if I understand correctly based on what the two of you have written above, keeping in mind that what I want to know is what a writer needs to know in order to do his/her job, publishing content on Pantheon 2:

Starting with milestone 2, which is kind of akin to an alpha release as far as writers are concerned, the only path to get content into Pantheon 2 for publishing is via git commit to a repository and then a sync in Pantheon.
After milestone 2, at some point in the future, in addition to publishing a document in Pantheon 2, for which I still will only use git commit to a repo and then a sync in Pantheon, Another function that will be made available in Pantheon 2 is to store a document in something called a sandbox, which is a workspace to store one or more documents that for some reason cannot be published. The method to populate sandboxes will primarily be the CLI tool, and there might be additional methods.

Questions:

When do you project that sandboxes and the attendant CLI uploader be availalbe for writers to use?
Why do I as a writer need to have a sandbox to store docs that can't be published? If it can't be published, why wouldn't I just use a branch in git for this purpose?
Why would a document not be able to be published?
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText: After all these comments, I just removed any mention of an uploader other than Gitlab/Github.
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText: @stoobie I was on vacation for the last 2.5 weeks, I'm back today. You have the right idea about the path to get docs into pantheon. If you'd still like to talk about your questions, let me know and we can discuss further.
replies.author: benradey

timeline.message: FCCEUD-8 Edited wording, moved list of features to a table.

timeline.bodyText: Was the comma intended here, or did you mean to end with a full stop?
timeline.author: robin-owen
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,36 @@
+[id='about-pantheon_{context}']
+= About Pantheon
+
+Pantheon is a content-management system and publishing platform developed by Red Hat.
+You can use it to publish documents based on AsciiDoc source.
+After adding your modules and assemblies to Pantheon, you can do the following:
+
+. Add metadata
+. Preview your content using the look and feel of the Customer Portal
+. Associate modules and assemblies with a product
+. Publish, and unpublish content
+
+The following table describes features that Pantheon does and does not provide.
+
+.Pantheon Features
+|===
+|Pantheon provides |Pantheon does not provide
+
+a|* A GUI for managing modules and assemblies, including the ability for authors to search for specific content and other workflow features that are more user-friendly than those currently available,

replies.bodyText: Good catch. I added periods to all of the items. Only the very last cell (about source control) actually needs one, but I added to the rest for consistency.
replies.author: stoobie

timeline.bodyText: Is a table the best way to represent this information? These feel more like lists than table contents to me.

replies.bodyText: I had two lists. This just looks cleaner and  easier to parse to me. 6 of 1, half a dozen of the other. If you feel strongly, I'll change it back to lists.
replies.author: stoobie

timeline.message: FCCEUD-8 Added periods to table cells.
FCCEUD-8 Removed mention of uploader. Now only mention Gitlab/Github as a way to get content into Pantheon.
